meanings.definition: To make amends or reparation for (guilt or wrongdoing)
meanings.sent1: She tried to expiate her mistake by apologizing sincerely.
meanings.sent2: He wanted to expiate his guilt by doing something good for others.
meanings.sent3: The cat knocked over the vase, but it couldn't expiate its actions by purring.
meanings.sent4: His hard work to expiate his past wrongs was like a beacon of hope.
meanings.sent5: The image of her tearful eyes trying to expiate her fault stayed with him.

meanings.sent1: He hoped to expiate his sins through prayer and reflection.
meanings.sent2: The community believed in rituals to expiate their wrongdoings.
meanings.sent3: The clown tried to expiate his silly mistakes by juggling bananas.
meanings.sent4: Her efforts to expiate her past were like a phoenix rising from the ashes.
meanings.sent5: The sound of the church bell echoed as he tried to expiate his transgressions.

meanings.definition: To make up for (a wrong or injury)
meanings.sent1: She wanted to expiate the damage she had caused by fixing it.
meanings.sent2: He tried to expiate the pain he had caused by being more caring.
meanings.sent3: The puppy tried to expiate chewing the shoe by bringing a toy as a peace offering.
meanings.sent4: His determination to expiate the harm done was like a shield against criticism.
meanings.sent5: The colors of the sunset seemed to expiate the darkness of the day.
